3.1.2 Meal Planning and AI Meal Generation (FR-005 to FR-010) ................................ 13
This Software Requirements Specification (SRS) document provides a comprehensive, precise, and
verifiable description of the functional and non-functional requirements for the Web-Based Meal
Planning Application (WBMPA). The primary purpose of this document is to serve as the authoritative
reference for the design, development, testing, deployment, and maintenance of the system throughout its
The SRS establishes a common understanding between all stakeholders by clearly defining system
behaviour, constraints, interfaces, quality attributes, and assumptions. It ensures that the implemented
system aligns with business objectives, user needs, and technical standards, while minimizing ambiguity
Define all system functionalities related to meal planning, grocery management, nutrition
Specify detailed requirements for AI-powered features, including Smart Grocery
Automation and AI-generated meal plans, with clearly defined inputs, outputs,
Provide a contractual and technical baseline against which system implementation and
Support developers in implementing the system using the prescribed technology stack
(Next.js, Node.js, PostgreSQL, Redis, and AI services)
Guide quality assurance teams in designing test cases and validation procedures
Assist product managers and stakeholders in evaluating scope, feasibility, risk, and
Facilitate future system maintenance, enhancement, and scalability by documenting
This document is intended for the following audiences:
Software engineers and architects responsible for system design and implementation.
Quality assurance and testing engineers responsible for system verification and
Product managers and project managers responsible for planning, scheduling, and
Business stakeholders, investors, and decision-makers evaluating product value and risk
Academic reviewers or auditors assessing compliance with IEEE SRS standards
The Meal Planning Application (MPA) is a software system designed to assist individuals and households
in planning meals, managing groceries, tracking nutrition, and optimizing food-related decisions through
the use of artificial intelligence and automation. The scope of this system encompasses end-to-end meal
planning workflows, from preference collection and meal generation to grocery procurement and
The system is intended to provide the following core capabilities:
Creation and management of personalized meal plans on a weekly or multi-week basis
Intelligent generation of grocery lists derived from selected meal plans • AI-powered
optimization of meals and grocery lists based on dietary preferences, nutritional goals,
Digital tracking of pantry and fridge items to reduce food waste and unnecessary
Nutrition analysis and reporting to support healthier eating habits
Nutrition analysis and reporting to support healthier eating habits
Household collaboration features enabling shared planning and shopping
The application is designed as a web-based platform accessible through modern browsers on desktop and
mobile devices. It will be implemented using a modern JavaScript-based technology stack, including
Next.js for the frontend, Node.js for the backend, relational and in-memory databases for data persistence
and caching, and integrated AI services for intelligent decision-making.
The scope of this paltform will also include:
User account management, authentication, and role-based access control • Manual and
Smart grocery automation, including cost-aware and waste-minimizing optimization.
Pantry and inventory management with alerts and notifications
Nutrition tracking, analytics, and report generation
Administrative tools for system configuration and monitoring
The scope of application will excludes:
Direct purchasing or payment processing for groceries
Integration with third-party grocery delivery services in the initial release
Offline-first functionality beyond basic browser caching
The system is intended to support personal wellness and household efficiency but is not a substitute for
professional medical, nutritional, or dietary advice. AI-generated recommendations are advisory in nature
and may be subject to limitations in data accuracy, availability, or interpretation.
Any functionality not explicitly described in this document shall be considered out of scope unless
formally approved through a documented change management process.
Weekly meal plan generation (breakfast, lunch, dinner, snacks)
Personalized meal planning based on dietary preferences, allergies, dislikes, and health
AI-generated smart grocery lists with deduplication and cost optimization
Recipe discovery, filtering, and cooking guidance
Nutrition tracking including calories, macronutrients, and micronutrients
Budget-aware meal planning and cost estimation
Pantry and fridge inventory-based meal suggestions
Batch cooking and meal prep planning
Consumption tracking and nutrition goal comparison
Multi-user household and shared pantry support
AI-powered Smart Grocery Automation and meal plan optimization
Improved dietary adherence and nutritional awareness
Reduced grocery expenses and food waste
Time savings through automation and planning
Scalable support for individuals and families
Medical diagnosis or clinical nutrition advice
IEEE Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
IEEE Std 830-1998: IEEE Recommended Practice for Software Requirements
ISO/IEC 25010: Systems and Software Quality Requirements and Evaluation
OWASP Top 10 Web Application Security Risks
The Web-Based Meal Planning Application is a new, modular, service-oriented web system.
Frontend: Next.js with React and TypeScript
Backend: Node.js using Express or NestJS
AI Services: OpenAI API or equivalent LLM provider
Authentication: JWT-based authentication with optional OAuth (Google/Apple)
Hosting: Cloud-based deployment using Docker and CI/CD pipelines
Account creation, login, and role-based access
Manual and AI-generated weekly meal plans
Email and optional push notifications for reminders and alerts
Frequency: Regular usage for planning and oversight
Regulatory: GDPR and applicable data protection laws
Technology: Must use Node.js, Next.js, and PostgreSQL
AI Dependency: Requires availability of third-party AI services
AI recommendations are advisory, not medical
OpenAI or equivalent LLM API availability
3.1.1 User Authentication and Account Management (FR-001 to FR-004)
Description: The system shall allow users to create an account using an email address and password or
The system shall validate email uniqueness during registration
Passwords shall meet defined complexity rules
Users shall verify their email address before accessing core features
Description: The system shall authenticate registered users before granting access to protected features.
OAuth login via Google or Apple shall be supported optionally
The system shall lock accounts temporarily after repeated failed login attempts
Description: The system shall allow users to securely reset forgotten passwords.
Reset links shall be time-bound and single-use
Password updates shall invalidate existing sessions
Description: The system shall support multiple roles including Individual User, Household
Household administrators shall manage members and shared resources
3.1.2 Meal Planning and AI Meal Generation (FR-005 to FR-010)
Description: Users shall be able to manually create weekly meal plans by selecting meals for breakfast,
Description: The system shall generate meal plans using AI based on user-defined inputs.
Inputs shall include dietary preferences, allergies, dislikes, nutrition goals, budget limits,
Outputs shall include a complete weekly meal plan with portion sizes
AI assumptions and limitations shall be disclosed to users
Description: Users shall be able to modify AI-generated meal plans.
FR-008: Batch Cooking and Meal Prep Planning
Description: The system shall support batch cooking recommendations and meal prep schedules.
Description: The system shall suggest meals that maximize use of existing pantry items.
Description: Users shall be able to plan meals across multiple weeks.
Description: Users shall search recipes by ingredients, cuisine, diet type, cooking time, and difficulty.
Description: The system shall display detailed recipes including ingredients, steps, nutrition data, and
Description: The system shall provide step-by-step cooking instructions and timers.
Description: Users shall save favorite recipes and provide ratings.
Description: The system shall recommend recipes using AI based on user behavior and preferences.
Description: The system shall generate grocery lists from selected meal plans.
Description: The system shall use AI to optimize grocery lists.
Description: The system shall adjust grocery lists to meet user-defined budgets.
FR-019: Pantry and Fridge Inventory Tracking
Description: Users shall manage pantry and fridge inventories.
Description: The system shall update inventory based on logged consumption.
Description: The system shall notify users of missing or low-stock items.
3.1.5 Nutrition Tracking and Analytics (FR-022 to FR-026)
Description: The system shall calculate calories, macronutrients, and micronutrients per meal.
FR-023: Daily and Weekly Nutrition Summaries
Description: The system shall aggregate nutrition intake over time.
FR-024: Goal Comparison and Progress Tracking
Description: The system shall compare intake against user-defined goals.
Description: The system shall present nutrition data using charts and summaries.
Description: Users shall export nutrition reports.
Description: The system shall send reminders for meals and preparation tasks.
Description: The system shall notify users when budgets are exceeded.
Description: Users shall configure notification settings.
Description: 95% of user requests shall complete within 2 seconds under normal load.
Description: The system shall support at least 1,000 concurrent users.
Description: Sensitive data shall be encrypted in transit and at rest using industry standards.
Description: Role-based access control shall be enforced.
Description: The system shall maintain 99.5% uptime.
Description: The system shall recover gracefully from failures.
Description: First-time users shall complete core tasks with minimal guidance.
Description: The system shall support modern browsers and responsive layouts.
This section specifies all external interfaces through which the Web-Based Meal Planning Application
(WBMPA) interacts with users, external systems, AI services, and data stores. These interfaces define
how information enters, exits, and flows through the system, and they serve as contractual boundaries
The interfaces described in this section are critical to ensuring interoperability, usability, security,
scalability, and maintainability of the system.
The WBMPA shall provide a responsive, browser-based graphical user interface (GUI) accessible via
modern desktop and mobile web browsers. The UI shall be designed to minimize cognitive load while
supporting complex planning and optimization workflows.
Clarity and simplicity over visual complexity
Consistent navigation and layout across all screens
Explicit differentiation between AI-generated suggestions and user-entered data
Progressive disclosure of advanced features (e.g., AI optimization details)
Responsive layout supporting screen widths from 360px to 1920px
Compliance with WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessibility guidelines
Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for text
Keyboard navigation support for all primary features
The system shall provide the following primary UI components:
Error messages shall not disclose sensitive system details
The dashboard shall act as the central control panel for users.
Pantry alerts (low stock or expiring items)
Weekly and multi-week calendar-style meal planner
Inline editing of meals and portions
Any meal or suggestion generated by AI shall be visually labeled (e.g., “AI Suggested”) with access to
All user actions shall receive immediate feedback
Errors shall be descriptive and actionable
AI-related failures shall degrade gracefully with fallback suggestions
WBMPA exposes and consumes RESTful APIs to support modularity, scalability, and integration.
The backend shall expose REST APIs consumed by the frontend.
The system shall integrate with third-party APIs including:
Purpose: Retrieve nutritional values for ingredients and recipes
Protocol: SMTP or API-based email service
Delivery failures shall be queued and retried
Standard HTTP status codes shall be used
AI services are a distinct external dependency and shall be treated as advisory subsystems, not
AI services shall be used exclusively for:
AI services shall be accessed via secure HTTPS APIs
Input data shall be minimized and anonymized
No personally identifiable information (PII) beyond required preferences shall be sent
Confidence scores or rationale text (when available)
Manual planning features shall remain functional
Previously cached AI results may be reused
Users shall be informed of limited AI availability
Where feasible, AI outputs shall include:
Short textual explanations (e.g., “Selected to reduce cost by 15%”)
Disclosure that results are probabilistic and advisory
Access Pattern: Backend-only (no direct client access)
ORM or query builder shall be used to prevent SQL injection
All multi-step operations (e.g., meal → grocery → pantry updates) shall be transactional
Rollback mechanisms shall be implemented on failure
Database credentials shall not be hard-coded
Access shall be restricted via least-privilege roles
Encryption at rest shall be enabled for sensitive fields
This section describes the high-level architecture of the Web-Based Meal Planning Application
(WBMPA). It defines the system’s structural organization, major components, their responsibilities, and
the interactions between them. The architecture is designed to support scalability, maintainability,
security, and modular integration of AI services, while ensuring a clear separation between user
facing, business logic, data management, and AI advisory layers.
The WBMPA shall adopt a layered, service-oriented architecture with clearly defined boundaries
The architecture is logically divided into the following layers:
Independent development and scaling of components
Controlled integration of AI as an advisory subsystem
Improved fault isolation and system resilience
Ease of future extension and integration
The Presentation Layer is responsible for all user interactions and client-side state management.
Display AI-generated recommendations with clear labeling
Communicate with backend APIs over HTTPS
Server-Side Rendering (SSR) for performance and SEO
No direct database or AI access
Technology: Node.js with Express.js or NestJS
The Application Layer implements all core business logic and acts as the system’s central coordinator.
Enforcement of business rules and constraints
All business logic shall reside in this layer
AI outputs shall be validated and filtered before use
Stateless API design to support horizontal scaling
The AI Services Layer provides probabilistic and advisory capabilities to enhance user experience and
Optimize grocery lists for cost and waste reduction
Provide explanation metadata for AI outputs
AI services shall never be directly accessed by the frontend
All AI requests shall pass through the backend
AI responses shall be treated as suggestions, not authoritative outputs
AI failures shall not block core system functionality
Persistent storage of structured application data
Efficient retrieval of frequently accessed data
This layer includes all third-party services that support non-core functionalities.
At runtime, the system components shall interact as follows:
The user interacts with the UI via a web browser.
The frontend sends authenticated requests to the backend APIs.
Retrieves or updates data in the database
The backend sends sanitized input to the AI services
The backend returns processed results to the frontend.
The frontend presents results with appropriate AI disclosure.
The WBMPA shall be deployable using a cloud-based infrastructure with the following logical
Each component shall be independently scalable.
Frontend and backend services shall support horizontal scaling
Stateless backend APIs shall enable load balancing
Redis shall be used to reduce database load
AI requests shall be rate-limited and cached when feasible
The architecture shall enforce security at every layer.
Below is a formal architecture diagram representing the WBMPA structure.
Enables controlled and ethical AI integration
Aligns with modern web application best practices
Is suitable for academic evaluation and real-world deployment
This section identifies the mandatory constraints, underlying assumptions, and external
dependencies that affect the design, development, deployment, and operation of the Web-Based Meal
Planning Application (WBMPA). These factors define the boundaries within which the system must
operate and are essential for risk assessment, feasibility analysis, and future system evolution.
System constraints are conditions or limitations imposed on the system that restrict design choices or
The application shall be implemented as a web-based system using:
The system shall rely on standard web browsers and shall not require native mobile or
All persistent data storage shall use a relational database system (PostgreSQL).
Real-time or session-related data shall be handled using Redis.
These constraints ensure compatibility, scalability, and alignment with modern web development
AI services shall be accessed only through external APIs and shall not be self-hosted
AI functionality shall be advisory only and shall not:
Make medical, nutritional, or health diagnoses
Enforce dietary restrictions beyond user-defined rules
Perform autonomous actions without user confirmation
AI outputs shall be treated as probabilistic suggestions and may vary across requests.
The system shall function correctly even when AI services are unavailable.
All system communications shall use HTTPS.
Personally identifiable information (PII) shall be processed in compliance with applicable
User passwords shall never be stored in plain text.
AI service requests shall exclude unnecessary PII.
The system shall support concurrent users without significant degradation in response
Average API response time for non-AI requests shall not exceed 2 seconds under normal
AI-generated responses may take longer but shall not block the user interface.
The system shall implement timeouts and fallback mechanisms for slow or unavailable
The system shall include clear disclaimers indicating that:
Meal and nutrition recommendations are informational only
The system does not replace professional dietary advice
AI decision-making processes shall be transparent where feasible.
The system shall not promote harmful dietary practices or unsafe food recommendations.
Assumptions are conditions believed to be true for the purpose of system design and operation.
Users have basic familiarity with web applications.
Users will provide accurate dietary preferences, allergies, and pantry information.
Users are responsible for validating food safety and health suitability.
Users will access the system via up-to-date web browsers.
Internet connectivity is available during system use.
Third-party APIs provide reliable and accurate data.
AI services return responses within acceptable time limits.
AI models are trained on general food and recipe data.
AI suggestions may require user review and adjustment.
System dependencies are external components or services required for WBMPA to function as intended.
AI service providers for meal planning and optimization
Nutrition data APIs for ingredient and recipe analysis
Email or notification services for system alerts
Failure or degradation of these services may result in partial system functionality.
Cloud hosting platform or server environment
6.4 Risk Considerations Related to Constraints and Dependencies
The system design shall account for risks arising from identified constraints and dependencies, including:
Mitigation strategies include caching, fallback mechanisms, input validation, and clear user
This section specifies the quality attributes and operational constraints of the Web-Based Meal Planning
Application (WBMPA). Non-functional requirements define how well the system performs its functions
rather than what functions it performs. These requirements are critical to system reliability, usability,
The system shall respond to standard user actions (excluding AI-generated operations)
AI-assisted operations shall provide user feedback (e.g., loading indicators) within 500
AI-generated results shall be delivered asynchronously to prevent UI blocking.
The system shall support at least 1,000 concurrent users without degradation of core
The backend shall process a minimum of 100 API requests per second under nominal
Backend services shall optimize memory and CPU usage to ensure horizontal scalability.
Cached data shall be used to reduce redundant database and AI calls.
The system shall maintain an uptime of 99.5% excluding scheduled maintenance.
Planned maintenance windows shall be communicated to users in advance.
Failure of AI services shall not cause system-wide failure.
Core features (manual meal planning, grocery list editing) shall remain operational during
Graceful degradation mechanisms shall be implemented.
All critical operations shall be transactional.
Data corruption shall be prevented through validation and rollback mechanisms.
The system shall enforce secure user authentication using industry-standard protocols.
Role-based access control (RBAC) shall restrict access to sensitive operations.
Sessions shall expire after periods of inactivity.
Sensitive user data shall be encrypted in transit and at rest.
Passwords shall be hashed using a strong cryptographic algorithm.
AI service requests shall minimize exposure of user data.
The system shall be protected against common web vulnerabilities (e.g., injection, XSS,
Rate limiting shall be enforced on public APIs.
Audit logs shall be maintained for security-relevant events.
The system shall be usable by non-technical users without training.
Core workflows (meal planning, grocery generation) shall require minimal steps.
The UI shall comply with WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessibility standards.
Keyboard navigation and screen reader support shall be provided.
AI-generated outputs shall be clearly labeled.
Users shall be informed when AI is used in decision support.
Explanations shall be provided where feasible.
The system shall support horizontal scaling of frontend and backend services.
Database performance shall be maintained through indexing and caching.
AI service usage shall scale via rate limiting and batching mechanisms.
The system shall be modular, with clear separation of concerns.
Changes to AI services shall not require frontend modifications.
The codebase shall follow consistent coding standards.
Automated testing shall be implemented for critical components.
Documentation shall be maintained for all public APIs.
The system shall be deployable across different cloud environments.
No vendor-specific features shall prevent migration.
Containerization may be used to ensure environment consistency.
The system shall comply with applicable data protection regulations.
The system shall include disclaimers for AI-generated recommendations.
AI shall not be used to enforce harmful or unsafe dietary behaviors.
System events shall be logged for monitoring and debugging.
Performance and error metrics shall be collected.
AI usage and failure rates shall be monitored.
The system shall support multiple measurement units.
The UI shall be designed to allow future language localization.
Regional dietary preferences shall be configurable.
This section presents abstract and graphical models that describe the structure and behavior of the Web
Based Meal Planning Application (WBMPA). System models are used to visualize system functionality,
data flow, component interactions, and user-system relationships. These models improve understanding,
support validation of requirements, and serve as a foundation for system design and implementation.
The models included in this section follow standard UML conventions and represent the system at an
The Use Case Model identifies the primary actors interacting with the system and the high-level services
provided by WBMPA. It captures what the system does from the user’s perspective, without exposing
A registered individual who plans meals, manages groceries, and interacts with AI
An external advisory system providing probabilistic meal and grocery recommendations.
Third-party systems such as nutrition data providers and email notification services.
2. User chooses manual or AI-assisted planning.
4. AI service generates suggested meals (if selected).
5. System filters AI output based on constraints.
6. Meal plan is presented to the user.
Meal plan is saved to the database.
If AI service is unavailable, system allows manual planning.
The sequence diagram illustrates the interaction between the user, frontend, backend, database, and AI
This activity diagram shows the decision flow between manual and AI-assisted meal planning.
The data model defines the key entities and their relationships within WBMPA. This is a conceptual
This model emphasizes the non-authoritative role of AI within the system.
All models presented in this section:
Are consistent with functional requirements in Section 3
Support quality attributes defined in Section 7
Clearly isolate AI as an advisory component and engineering justification
This section describes the logical and conceptual database design for the Web-Based Meal Planning
Application (WBMPA). The database is designed to ensure data integrity, consistency, scalability, and
security, while supporting all functional and non-functional requirements defined earlier in this
The database design follows a relational model, with normalization applied to reduce redundancy and
Database Type: Relational Database Management System (RDBMS)
Access Control: Backend-only access via ORM or parameterized queries
The database stores all core application data, while Redis is used for temporary data, session
The database design adheres to the following principles:
Data Normalization: Minimize redundancy and update anomalies
Referential Integrity: Enforce relationships using foreign keys
Security: Protect sensitive fields and restrict access
Scalability: Support growth in users and data volume
Traceability: Align entities directly with system models (Section 8)
Represents meal plans created by users.
Stores individual meals within a meal plan.
Associative entity linking recipes and ingredients.
Stores items in a grocery list.
AI-related data shall be stored in a limited and non-sensitive manner.
Type of AI operation (meal planning, optimization)
Primary and foreign keys enforce referential integrity
Check constraints validate quantities and dates
Transactions ensure atomic updates across related tables
Regular automated backups shall be performed
Backup data shall be encrypted and access-controlled
This section provides supplementary information that supports understanding, implementation, and
maintenance of the WBMPA but is not part of the core requirements.
The system does not provide medical or dietary advice
Users retain full responsibility for food choices and health decisions
AI outputs may be incomplete or inaccurate
AI services behave within expected parameters

The Meal Planning Application (MPA) is a software system designed to assist individuals and households
in planning meals, managing groceries, tracking nutrition, and optimizing food-related decisions through
the use of artificial intelligence and automation. The scope of this system encompasses end-to-end meal
planning workflows, from preference collection and meal generation to grocery procurement and
The system is intended to provide the following core capabilities:
Creation and management of personalized meal plans on a weekly or multi-week basis
Intelligent generation of grocery lists derived from selected meal plans • AI-powered
optimization of meals and grocery lists based on dietary preferences, nutritional goals,
Digital tracking of pantry and fridge items to reduce food waste and unnecessary
Nutrition analysis and reporting to support healthier eating habits
Nutrition analysis and reporting to support healthier eating habits
Household collaboration features enabling shared planning and shopping
The application is designed as a web-based platform accessible through modern browsers on desktop and
mobile devices. It will be implemented using a modern JavaScript-based technology stack, including
Next.js for the frontend, Node.js for the backend, relational and in-memory databases for data persistence
and caching, and integrated AI services for intelligent decision-making.
The scope of this paltform will also include:
User account management, authentication, and role-based access control • Manual and
Smart grocery automation, including cost-aware and waste-minimizing optimization.

professional medical, nutritional, or dietary advice. AI-generated recommendations are advisory in nature
and may be subject to limitations in data accuracy, availability, or interpretation.
Any functionality not explicitly described in this document shall be considered out of scope unless
formally approved through a documented change management process.

This section specifies all external interfaces through which the Web-Based Meal Planning Application
(WBMPA) interacts with users, external systems, AI services, and data stores. These interfaces define
how information enters, exits, and flows through the system, and they serve as contractual boundaries
The interfaces described in this section are critical to ensuring interoperability, usability, security,
scalability, and maintainability of the system.
The WBMPA shall provide a responsive, browser-based graphical user interface (GUI) accessible via
modern desktop and mobile web browsers. The UI shall be designed to minimize cognitive load while
supporting complex planning and optimization workflows.
Clarity and simplicity over visual complexity
Consistent navigation and layout across all screens
Explicit differentiation between AI-generated suggestions and user-entered data
Progressive disclosure of advanced features (e.g., AI optimization details)
Responsive layout supporting screen widths from 360px to 1920px
Compliance with WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessibility guidelines
Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for text
Keyboard navigation support for all primary features
The system shall provide the following primary UI components:
Error messages shall not disclose sensitive system details
The dashboard shall act as the central control panel for users.
Pantry alerts (low stock or expiring items)
Weekly and multi-week calendar-style meal planner
Inline editing of meals and portions
Any meal or suggestion generated by AI shall be visually labeled (e.g., “AI Suggested”) with access to
All user actions shall receive immediate feedback
Errors shall be descriptive and actionable
AI-related failures shall degrade gracefully with fallback suggestions
WBMPA exposes and consumes RESTful APIs to support modularity, scalability, and integration.
The backend shall expose REST APIs consumed by the frontend.
The system shall integrate with third-party APIs including:
Purpose: Retrieve nutritional values for ingredients and recipes
Protocol: SMTP or API-based email service
Delivery failures shall be queued and retried
Standard HTTP status codes shall be used
AI services are a distinct external dependency and shall be treated as advisory subsystems, not
AI services shall be used exclusively for:
AI services shall be accessed via secure HTTPS APIs
Input data shall be minimized and anonymized
No personally identifiable information (PII) beyond required preferences shall be sent
Confidence scores or rationale text (when available)
Manual planning features shall remain functional
Previously cached AI results may be reused
Users shall be informed of limited AI availability
Where feasible, AI outputs shall include:
Short textual explanations (e.g., “Selected to reduce cost by 15%”)
Disclosure that results are probabilistic and advisory
Access Pattern: Backend-only (no direct client access)
ORM or query builder shall be used to prevent SQL injection
All multi-step operations (e.g., meal → grocery → pantry updates) shall be transactional
Rollback mechanisms shall be implemented on failure
Database credentials shall not be hard-coded
Access shall be restricted via least-privilege roles
Encryption at rest shall be enabled for sensitive fields
This section describes the high-level architecture of the Web-Based Meal Planning Application
(WBMPA). It defines the system’s structural organization, major components, their responsibilities, and
the interactions between them. The architecture is designed to support scalability, maintainability,
security, and modular integration of AI services, while ensuring a clear separation between user
facing, business logic, data management, and AI advisory layers.
The WBMPA shall adopt a layered, service-oriented architecture with clearly defined boundaries
The architecture is logically divided into the following layers:
Independent development and scaling of components
Controlled integration of AI as an advisory subsystem
Improved fault isolation and system resilience
Ease of future extension and integration
The Presentation Layer is responsible for all user interactions and client-side state management.
Display AI-generated recommendations with clear labeling
Communicate with backend APIs over HTTPS
Server-Side Rendering (SSR) for performance and SEO
No direct database or AI access
Technology: Node.js with Express.js or NestJS
The Application Layer implements all core business logic and acts as the system’s central coordinator.
Enforcement of business rules and constraints
All business logic shall reside in this layer
AI outputs shall be validated and filtered before use
Stateless API design to support horizontal scaling
The AI Services Layer provides probabilistic and advisory capabilities to enhance user experience and
Optimize grocery lists for cost and waste reduction
Provide explanation metadata for AI outputs
AI services shall never be directly accessed by the frontend
All AI requests shall pass through the backend
AI responses shall be treated as suggestions, not authoritative outputs
AI failures shall not block core system functionality
Persistent storage of structured application data
Efficient retrieval of frequently accessed data
This layer includes all third-party services that support non-core functionalities.
At runtime, the system components shall interact as follows:
The user interacts with the UI via a web browser.
The frontend sends authenticated requests to the backend APIs.
Retrieves or updates data in the database
The backend sends sanitized input to the AI services
The backend returns processed results to the frontend.
The frontend presents results with appropriate AI disclosure.
The WBMPA shall be deployable using a cloud-based infrastructure with the following logical
Each component shall be independently scalable.
Frontend and backend services shall support horizontal scaling
Stateless backend APIs shall enable load balancing
Redis shall be used to reduce database load
AI requests shall be rate-limited and cached when feasible
The architecture shall enforce security at every layer.
Below is a formal architecture diagram representing the WBMPA structure.
Enables controlled and ethical AI integration
Aligns with modern web application best practices
Is suitable for academic evaluation and real-world deployment
This section identifies the mandatory constraints, underlying assumptions, and external
dependencies that affect the design, development, deployment, and operation of the Web-Based Meal
Planning Application (WBMPA). These factors define the boundaries within which the system must
operate and are essential for risk assessment, feasibility analysis, and future system evolution.
System constraints are conditions or limitations imposed on the system that restrict design choices or
The application shall be implemented as a web-based system using:
The system shall rely on standard web browsers and shall not require native mobile or
All persistent data storage shall use a relational database system (PostgreSQL).
Real-time or session-related data shall be handled using Redis.
These constraints ensure compatibility, scalability, and alignment with modern web development
AI services shall be accessed only through external APIs and shall not be self-hosted
AI functionality shall be advisory only and shall not:
Make medical, nutritional, or health diagnoses
Enforce dietary restrictions beyond user-defined rules
Perform autonomous actions without user confirmation
AI outputs shall be treated as probabilistic suggestions and may vary across requests.
The system shall function correctly even when AI services are unavailable.
All system communications shall use HTTPS.
Personally identifiable information (PII) shall be processed in compliance with applicable
User passwords shall never be stored in plain text.
AI service requests shall exclude unnecessary PII.
The system shall support concurrent users without significant degradation in response
Average API response time for non-AI requests shall not exceed 2 seconds under normal
AI-generated responses may take longer but shall not block the user interface.
The system shall implement timeouts and fallback mechanisms for slow or unavailable
The system shall include clear disclaimers indicating that:
Meal and nutrition recommendations are informational only
The system does not replace professional dietary advice
AI decision-making processes shall be transparent where feasible.
The system shall not promote harmful dietary practices or unsafe food recommendations.
Assumptions are conditions believed to be true for the purpose of system design and operation.
Users have basic familiarity with web applications.
Users will provide accurate dietary preferences, allergies, and pantry information.
Users are responsible for validating food safety and health suitability.
Users will access the system via up-to-date web browsers.
Internet connectivity is available during system use.
Third-party APIs provide reliable and accurate data.
AI services return responses within acceptable time limits.
AI models are trained on general food and recipe data.
AI suggestions may require user review and adjustment.
System dependencies are external components or services required for WBMPA to function as intended.
AI service providers for meal planning and optimization
Nutrition data APIs for ingredient and recipe analysis
Email or notification services for system alerts
Failure or degradation of these services may result in partial system functionality.
Cloud hosting platform or server environment
6.4 Risk Considerations Related to Constraints and Dependencies
The system design shall account for risks arising from identified constraints and dependencies, including:
Mitigation strategies include caching, fallback mechanisms, input validation, and clear user
This section specifies the quality attributes and operational constraints of the Web-Based Meal Planning
Application (WBMPA). Non-functional requirements define how well the system performs its functions
rather than what functions it performs. These requirements are critical to system reliability, usability,
The system shall respond to standard user actions (excluding AI-generated operations)
AI-assisted operations shall provide user feedback (e.g., loading indicators) within 500
AI-generated results shall be delivered asynchronously to prevent UI blocking.
The system shall support at least 1,000 concurrent users without degradation of core
The backend shall process a minimum of 100 API requests per second under nominal
Backend services shall optimize memory and CPU usage to ensure horizontal scalability.
Cached data shall be used to reduce redundant database and AI calls.
The system shall maintain an uptime of 99.5% excluding scheduled maintenance.
Planned maintenance windows shall be communicated to users in advance.
Failure of AI services shall not cause system-wide failure.
Core features (manual meal planning, grocery list editing) shall remain operational during
Graceful degradation mechanisms shall be implemented.
All critical operations shall be transactional.
Data corruption shall be prevented through validation and rollback mechanisms.
The system shall enforce secure user authentication using industry-standard protocols.
Role-based access control (RBAC) shall restrict access to sensitive operations.
Sessions shall expire after periods of inactivity.
Sensitive user data shall be encrypted in transit and at rest.
Passwords shall be hashed using a strong cryptographic algorithm.
AI service requests shall minimize exposure of user data.
The system shall be protected against common web vulnerabilities (e.g., injection, XSS,
Rate limiting shall be enforced on public APIs.
Audit logs shall be maintained for security-relevant events.
The system shall be usable by non-technical users without training.
Core workflows (meal planning, grocery generation) shall require minimal steps.
The UI shall comply with WCAG 2.1 Level AA accessibility standards.
Keyboard navigation and screen reader support shall be provided.
AI-generated outputs shall be clearly labeled.
Users shall be informed when AI is used in decision support.
Explanations shall be provided where feasible.
The system shall support horizontal scaling of frontend and backend services.
Database performance shall be maintained through indexing and caching.
AI service usage shall scale via rate limiting and batching mechanisms.
The system shall be modular, with clear separation of concerns.
Changes to AI services shall not require frontend modifications.
The codebase shall follow consistent coding standards.
Automated testing shall be implemented for critical components.
Documentation shall be maintained for all public APIs.
The system shall be deployable across different cloud environments.
No vendor-specific features shall prevent migration.
Containerization may be used to ensure environment consistency.
The system shall comply with applicable data protection regulations.
The system shall include disclaimers for AI-generated recommendations.
AI shall not be used to enforce harmful or unsafe dietary behaviors.
System events shall be logged for monitoring and debugging.
Performance and error metrics shall be collected.
AI usage and failure rates shall be monitored.
The system shall support multiple measurement units.
The UI shall be designed to allow future language localization.
Regional dietary preferences shall be configurable.
This section presents abstract and graphical models that describe the structure and behavior of the Web
Based Meal Planning Application (WBMPA). System models are used to visualize system functionality,
data flow, component interactions, and user-system relationships. These models improve understanding,
support validation of requirements, and serve as a foundation for system design and implementation.
The models included in this section follow standard UML conventions and represent the system at an
The Use Case Model identifies the primary actors interacting with the system and the high-level services
provided by WBMPA. It captures what the system does from the user’s perspective, without exposing
A registered individual who plans meals, manages groceries, and interacts with AI
An external advisory system providing probabilistic meal and grocery recommendations.
Third-party systems such as nutrition data providers and email notification services.
2. User chooses manual or AI-assisted planning.
4. AI service generates suggested meals (if selected).
5. System filters AI output based on constraints.
6. Meal plan is presented to the user.
Meal plan is saved to the database.
If AI service is unavailable, system allows manual planning.
The sequence diagram illustrates the interaction between the user, frontend, backend, database, and AI
This activity diagram shows the decision flow between manual and AI-assisted meal planning.
The data model defines the key entities and their relationships within WBMPA. This is a conceptual
This model emphasizes the non-authoritative role of AI within the system.
All models presented in this section:
Are consistent with functional requirements in Section 3
Support quality attributes defined in Section 7
Clearly isolate AI as an advisory component and engineering justification
This section describes the logical and conceptual database design for the Web-Based Meal Planning
Application (WBMPA). The database is designed to ensure data integrity, consistency, scalability, and
security, while supporting all functional and non-functional requirements defined earlier in this
The database design follows a relational model, with normalization applied to reduce redundancy and
Database Type: Relational Database Management System (RDBMS)
Access Control: Backend-only access via ORM or parameterized queries
The database stores all core application data, while Redis is used for temporary data, session
The database design adheres to the following principles:
Data Normalization: Minimize redundancy and update anomalies
Referential Integrity: Enforce relationships using foreign keys
Security: Protect sensitive fields and restrict access
Scalability: Support growth in users and data volume
Traceability: Align entities directly with system models (Section 8)
Represents meal plans created by users.
Stores individual meals within a meal plan.
Associative entity linking recipes and ingredients.
Stores items in a grocery list.
AI-related data shall be stored in a limited and non-sensitive manner.
Type of AI operation (meal planning, optimization)
Primary and foreign keys enforce referential integrity
Check constraints validate quantities and dates
Transactions ensure atomic updates across related tables
Regular automated backups shall be performed
Backup data shall be encrypted and access-controlled
This section provides supplementary information that supports understanding, implementation, and
maintenance of the WBMPA but is not part of the core requirements.
The system does not provide medical or dietary advice
Users retain full responsibility for food choices and health decisions
AI outputs may be incomplete or inaccurate
AI services behave within expected parameters
